content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose strategy that maximizes my total payoff over 75 rounds. If I pick R consistently, then in each round where they pick R too, I get 45$. However, in all the other rounds where they pick B, I get 0$. Since there are more B choices (68 out of 75), I would end up with less than 45$ for most of the rounds.

On the other hand, if I pick B consistently, then in each round where they pick R, I still get 35$, which is not bad. And in the majority of rounds (68 out of 75) when they also pick B, I get 40$. This strategy would provide a more stable and higher average payoff.

So, based on this reasoning, my choice would be B{B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.
In this case, since my opponent also chose B, I will choose R for the next round to try and maximize my potential payoffs. So, my choice for the next round would be R{R}.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 35$. Please play the next round.

In this situation, I understand that choosing R when my opponent chose B resulted in a zero payoff for me. However, I will continue playing the game to see if there are opportunities for higher payoffs later on. To try and maximize my potential payoffs, I will choose B for the next round. So, my choice for the next round would be B{B}.
